snippet: For low-risk inmates, early release into parole should be the default and the board should have to articulate a good reason to keep them locked up.
abstract: Editorial criticizes parole board in New York State for denying parole to low-risk inmates with exemplary prison records; holds board follows outdated practice of weighing seriousness of original crime rather than progress of the individual; contends that lasting reform of parole system will require reworking of both board's process and its culture.
lead_paragraph: For low-risk inmates, early release into parole should be the default and the board should have to articulate a good reason to keep them locked up.
